note.p: Content sourced from Saratoga Device Specification - Issue 12

body.p: Switchtec introduces a unique partitioning scheme which provides a controlled mapping layer that allows for dynamic mapping of physical ports to P2P bridge functions. This scheme makes the relationship of physical ports and switch P2P bridges not 1:1. There can be far more switch P2P bridges than physical ports allowing switchtec to present P2P bridges to the host that are not mapped to physical ports.
This mapping layer allows for dynamic migration of physical ports between active partitions, and provides the following features:

li.p: Hosts in each partition configure the switch to support all potential targets on physical ports.
Migrating ports between partitions are supported natively with no OS, BIOS or driver modifications.
Migrating ports appear as hot-add and hot-remove events.

body.p: illustrates the Switchtec implementation of dynamic partitioning where there are a total of 5 physical ports and two hosts. In this example, each host (orange and green) is able to see 5 P2P bridges but the orange host only has two Endpoints attached while the green host only has three Endpoints attached. MRPC can be used to dynamically shift physical ports (PCIe SSDs in this example) between hosts without having to reboot the hosts.
When referring to logical P2Ps, Switchtec makes two unique distinctions:

li.p: Normal P2P Bridge - This is a P2P that is bound to a real physical port on the switch and appears as an empty slot to the host if no EP is connected to the port
Shadow P2P Bridge - This is a P2P that is unbound to a physical port on the switch and appears as an empty slot to the host
